snippet.textDisplay: I still find myself dumbfounded by people who wear masks that ride below their noses and people who wear flimsy one-layer paper masks. While the former defies reason and common sense, the latter provides near zero protection, though it may impart some false sense of comfort/safety to the wearer.

snippet.textDisplay: @gabe shutt It’s a form of ignorance.
snippet.textOriginal: @gabe shutt It’s a form of ignorance.

snippet.textDisplay: @gabe shutt No, risking being tear-gas, or charged upon by a phalanx of coppers in full riot gear, or marching past a government building and seeing a line of rifle barrels with fixed bayonets sticking above the roofline, those are indicators, among others, that one is engaged in civil disobedience. Walking about looking like a twit does not constitute civil disobedience; rather it is a display of flagrant disregard for the health of others' with whom one comes in contact. Remember all the "super-spreader" events filled with maskless people all cheek to jowl. Don't romanticize a selfish act.

snippet.textDisplay:
@Zekey Beats So that whole bin of pronouncements about "social distancing" was just a bunch of bollocks, yeah?
Cheers

snippet.textDisplay: @Ray Stanczak you can sit beside someone in a subway with the cheaper masks with no risk of transmission. The virus is only transmitted through those water droplets in your breath. They work pretty well.
snippet.textOriginal: @Ray Stanczak you can sit beside someone in a subway with the cheaper masks with no risk of transmission. The virus is only transmitted through those water droplets in your breath. They work pretty well.

snippet.textDisplay:
One correction—the flimsy masks ARE effective, but in a limited but still very useful way. (If I’m remembering correctly, the source was Dr. Michael Osterholm, U.of Minnesota Infectious Disease Department.)
  In a situation where distance is maintained and the space is large, ventilated, or outdoors, the flimsy mask will catch droplets that are outgoing. They will offer some limited filtering of the incoming air.
  The places where I feel quite safe wearing a lower quality mask—due to distance and ventilation—are grocery stores, mass transit, walking on streets with others, sitting outdoors.
  In a closed room, or when in close contact with people, an M-95 is necessary.
  The studies I’ve seen on the efficacy of different face coverings are given in “time”—how much time can you safely spend in situations where virus is present, with different face coverings. It ranges from a few minutes with a paper mask, all the way to 20+ hours with a properly fitted M-95.
  We need to know how to accurately gauge the level of protection needed apropos to the situation. That reduces the level of generalized stress that’s just “in the air” when you encounter something novel like this virus.
